reviews.review_msg: HSCI 321 is probably one of the most challenging classes in the HSCI Life Sci stream (after MBB 331 and ochem) but Dr. Koelwyn is beyond kind and very supportive in the students' learning. He is one of the best professors I have had at SFU to date and actually made the notoriously difficult pathophysiology enjoyable! Highly recommend. :)

321 is a tough class but Graeme makes it pretty enjoyable! Tests are pretty fair, albeit they are a bit more application based, case studies are a nice addition too as long as your group is good. He is also very caring and understanding, super cool guy. Very helpful with grading(adjusted our grades a bit) and overall is just really caring and kind.
Great prof! The only problem was the course he was teaching. Contents were as dense as the black hole (well maybe less than 331 but still).

Amazing experience with Dr. Graeme Koelwyn. Lectures are definitely heavy and require in-depth understanding, but this course is hard as-is and Dr. Graeme is excellent in properly explaining these difficult concepts. He is also very kind and approachable. Exams are fair and all the content is from his notes and lectures. I am glad I took his class.

He is very approachable and is willing to take his time to answer all of your questions. He is genuinely a caring prof. Makes the exams fair. Even though the course is very content heavy he try his best on emphasizing key concepts you should be aware of for the exam. Overall one of the best profs I had in al my HSCI courses by far.

He is an amazing professor. He tells you what is going to be tested and does not try to trick you on exams. The course is content heavy so you cannot cram for this class. If you stay caught up with material, you will do great. He is very helpful and goes into detail when you ask questions. I highly recommend taking a class with this professor.

DO NOT RECOMMEND! The lectures are disorganized, with complicated language on the slides that's hard to understand. Despite saying the textbook isn't necessary, the exam questions are mostly from it. The professor also fails to define many of the words used, adding to the confusion. Choose a different professor if you can!
